text:
It was noted a while ago on the bird site that a disproportionate number of Julia users are cyclists.

Straw pole.
React with
:bicyclist: if you cycle at least once a month.
React with :no_entry: if not.

text: You labeling people who bike once a month as "cyclist" makes me think that it's highly sensitive to where you come from :sweat_smile:

elements.text: You labeling people who bike once a month as "cyclist" makes me think that it's highly sensitive to where you come from

text: Relevant to Jakob's point: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vMed1qceJ_Q>

elements.text: Relevant to Jakob's point:

text: here on long island people who ride bicycles are a fairly hated demographic I'd say :laughing:

elements.text: here on long island people who ride bicycles are a fairly hated demographic I'd say

text: I would kind of like one to ride down into the village in the summer, but I don't really have a place to put one

text:
> You labeling people who bike once a month as "cyclist" makes me think that it's highly sensitive to where you come from :sweat_smile:

It seemed a lowest common denominator.

elements.text: > You labeling people who bike once a month as "cyclist" makes me think that it's highly sensitive to where you come from

text:
> here on long island people who ride bicycles are a fairly hated demographic I'd say
yeah, that's what that above video is kidna about. He talks about how in toronto, if you ever commute by bike at all, you're now a "cyclist" in everyone's eyes which is a pretty dirty word there.

elements.text: here on long island people who ride bicycles are a fairly hated demographic I'd say
yeah, that's what that above video is kidna about. He talks about how in toronto, if you ever commute by bike at all, you're now a "cyclist" in everyone's eyes which is a pretty dirty word there.

text: :+1: for Not Just Bikes :100:

elements.text: for Not Just Bikes

text: It's a really cool channel. Started watching last fall and it's really changed how I look at all the infrastructure around me. I never thought I'd find city planning so interesting to think about

elements.text: It's a really cool channel. Started watching last fall and it's really changed how I look at all the infrastructure around me. I never thought I'd find city planning so interesting to think about

text: perhaps what you're observing is that a disproportionate number of julia users are european?

elements.text: perhaps what you're observing is that a disproportionate number of julia users are european?

text: yeah, here very few people ride bikes and it certainly isn't possible to use them for any more than leisure, so they are seen as an irritant.  I partake in this attitude sometimes myself: sometimes some jackass for some unfathomable reason thinks it's appropriate to ride his bike in the middle of the goddamn road like it's a car, and I have much profanity for those people

elements.text: yeah, here very few people ride bikes and it certainly isn't possible to use them for any more than leisure, so they are seen as an irritant.  I partake in this attitude sometimes myself: sometimes some jackass for some unfathomable reason thinks it's appropriate to ride his bike in the middle of the goddamn road like it's a car, and I have much profanity for those people

text: It's a weird vicious cycle. Noone wants to bike because there is no infrastructure for biking, and noone wants to build that infrastructure because there are no bikes

elements.text: It's a weird vicious cycle. Noone wants to bike because there is no infrastructure for biking, and noone wants to build that infrastructure because there are no bikes

text: Yeah <@U8D9768Q6> I've been on a bit of a city planning tear as well. City Beautiful is another great channel if you haven't already seen it.

elements.text: Yeah
I've been on a bit of a city planning tear as well. City Beautiful is another great channel if you haven't already seen it.

text: It's worse when adults think it's acceptable to ride their bikes on the sidewalk or in parks on pedestrian paths. The reality is that much of north america is a car-centric hellscape.

elements.text: It's worse when adults think it's acceptable to ride their bikes on the sidewalk or in parks on pedestrian paths. The reality is that much of north america is a car-centric hellscape.

text: I.e. I live downtown in a midsized city and cannot grocery shop without a car.

elements.text: I.e. I live downtown in a midsized city and cannot grocery shop without a car.

text: I happen to really like having a car, I don't see it as a bad thing at all.  The absurd concept that everyone should have to commute to work is a bad thing; thank god covid has done so much to dispell it

elements.text: I happen to really like having a car, I don't see it as a bad thing at all.  The absurd concept that everyone should have to commute to work is a bad thing; thank god covid has done so much to dispell it

text: Having a car is fine and often useful, I don't like that it's a basic requirement for function in much of north america.

elements.text: Having a car is fine and often useful, I don't like that it's a basic requirement for function in much of north america.

text: yeah, I lived in Manhattan for 3 years, anyone driving a car there is out of their damn mind, but I don't see that as a good thing, I see it as a reason to live in a less densely populated place

elements.text: yeah, I lived in Manhattan for 3 years, anyone driving a car there is out of their damn mind, but I don't see that as a good thing, I see it as a reason to live in a less densely populated place

text: I can't begin to describe how pleasurable sitting in my car is compared to being in the NYC subway

elements.text: I can't begin to describe how pleasurable sitting in my car is compared to being in the NYC subway

text: Walking down the street is better than both IMO. The NYC subway might suck but public transit doesn't need to suck, cities just need to invest into them more. See singapore for instace.

elements.text: Walking down the street is better than both IMO. The NYC subway might suck but public transit doesn't need to suck, cities just need to invest into them more. See singapore for instace.

text: I have a bone to pick with cyclists since they have a knack for almost running me over

elements.text: I have a bone to pick with cyclists since they have a knack for almost running me over

text: Most cyclists could probably say the same thing about drivers :joy:

elements.text: Most cyclists could probably say the same thing about drivers

text: If you're a motorist, you hate pedestrians, if you're a pedestrian, you hate motorists, but no matter what your mode of transportation, you always hate byciclists

elements.text: If you're a motorist, you hate pedestrians, if you're a pedestrian, you hate motorists, but no matter what your mode of transportation, you always hate byciclists

text: True, even if you're a cyclist :sweat_smile: having dedicated bike lanes does really help, though. Bikes don't really fit on paved road, nor on the sidewalk

elements.text: True, even if you're a cyclist
having dedicated bike lanes does really help, though. Bikes don't really fit on paved road, nor on the sidewalk

text: yeah, bikes are really only good in places where nobody is around

elements.text: yeah, bikes are really only good in places where nobody is around

text: I think regardless of whether being a driver is more pleasureable than other modes of transportation, it’s another question to ask how much our governments should be subsidizing that mode of transportation given that it’s becoming painfully obvious that it doesn’t scale

elements.text: I think regardless of whether being a driver is more pleasureable than other modes of transportation, it’s another question to ask how much our governments should be subsidizing that mode of transportation given that it’s becoming painfully obvious that it doesn’t scale

text: I don’t think a single Danish person, below 90 and with two legs, cycle less than once per month. I’ve definitely never met one.

elements.text: I don’t think a single Danish person, below 90 and with two legs, cycle less than once per month. I’ve definitely never met one.

text: My girlfriend refuses to bike, so there is at least N=1

elements.text: My girlfriend refuses to bike, so there is at least N=1

text:
Regarding the NYC subway being unpleasant to use, this is a rather common trend in North America where public infrastructure gets defunded or put on life support, and then people use the decay of that infrastructure as a justification for why the infrastructure is a bad idea and to further defund it.

It’s a vicious cycle that’s hard to break free from.

elements.text:
Regarding the NYC subway being unpleasant to use, this is a rather common trend in North America where public infrastructure gets defunded or put on life support, and then people use the decay of that infrastructure as a justification for why the infrastructure is a bad idea and to further defund it.

It’s a vicious cycle that’s hard to break free from.

text: At my first internship in Silicon Valley, all interns could borrow nice road bikes if they wanted. A lot of people got one, but then half of them, mostly Americans, couldn't ride at all, almost falling off immediately. I think I've really never met a person in Germany that can't ride a bike, my mind was blown :)

elements.text: At my first internship in Silicon Valley, all interns could borrow nice road bikes if they wanted. A lot of people got one, but then half of them, mostly Americans, couldn't ride at all, almost falling off immediately. I think I've really never met a person in Germany that can't ride a bike, my mind was blown :)

text:
My friend did a research term at Los Alamos and was very perplexed when he was told that they could give him a car for the duration of his stay, but not a bicycle. 

Apparently there weren’t even sidewalks in most places, and there was some uncertainty over whether the guards at the gate would even let him into the lab if he walked or biked up instead of drove.

elements.text:
My friend did a research term at Los Alamos and was very perplexed when he was told that they could give him a car for the duration of his stay, but not a bicycle. 

Apparently there weren’t even sidewalks in most places, and there was some uncertainty over whether the guards at the gate would even let him into the lab if he walked or biked up instead of drove.

text: If Los Alamos is anything like nearby Arizona you would be really foolish to want to bike there. Your tires can melt.

elements.text: If Los Alamos is anything like nearby Arizona you would be really foolish to want to bike there. Your tires can melt.
